content: at its widest point end on a rs row for a larger deeper bonnet you can continue knitting but you will want to stop approximately 1 inch less than your desired length finishing the head youwillnowcreatethegarterstitchedgingonthefrontofthebonnet row 1 with ws of the fabric facing knit all stitches row 2 with rs of the fabric facing knit all stitches row 3 5 7 9 repeat row 1 row 4 6 8 repeat row 2 row 10 cast o� using your preferred method i used the jenny s surprisingly stretchy bind-o� method but any bind-o� will do cut the working yarn adding the ties youwillnowaddthebottombrimofthehatandthetiesinonefellswoop 5 row 1 using your circular needle cast on 75 stitches then with the rs of the hat facing you pick up the bottom edge of the hat the size of the hat will dictate just how many stitches you pick up using my gauge and dimensions i picked up a total of 78 stitches the most important thing here is to ensure you pick up an even number of stitches on both sides of the hat with the back of the hat as the midpoint after you have picked up the bottom edge of the hat cast on an additional 75 stitches your circular needle should now have a total of 228 stitches ready to knit row 2 with ws of the fabric facing knit all stitches row 3 with rs of the fabric facing knit all stitches row 4 6 8 10 with ws of the fabric facing knit all stitches row 5 7 9 with rs of the fabric facing knit all stitches row 11 cast o� using your preferred method i used the jenny s surprisingly stretchy bind-o� method but any bind-o� will do cut yarn and weave in all ends go forth and be fabulous 6
